item.title: 55 – Work Day Haiku
item.dc:creator: Graham
item.description: Work Day Haiku sad haiku reader always counting syllables words clunk like staplers * boring staff meeting I name every freckle on her neck Jolene is one of the Dakotas * such relief: odd trays in the fridge for takeout, … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Work Day Haiku

sad haiku reader
always counting syllables
words clunk like staplers

*

boring staff meeting
I name every freckle on her neck
Jolene is one of the Dakotas

*

such relief:
odd trays in the fridge
for takeout, not breast milk

*

three-thirty slump
fun-size KitKat found in top drawer
data entry is the best!

*

across the bar
a woman w/a nicotine patch
new tattoo or cancer

*

heading home late
empty river flows pensive
bulleted by rain

*

unfinished art
breathing on the screen
publish anyway

item.title: 54 – Hangover
item.dc:creator: Graham
item.description: Hangover It’s been a luxurious weekend of friends and over-eating late night board games red red wine white sheets in a bed too big waking up late and wondering what to do with the day then the long slow haul … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Hangover

It’s been a luxurious weekend
of friends and over-eating
late night board games
red red wine white sheets
in a bed too big waking up late
and wondering what to do with the day
then the long slow haul back
through Oregon’s central expanse
(which I love in a way
I can’t quite comprehend
or convey and which I expect
Heaven to emulate—distinct
but blurred at the edges
by shifting light caught
behind tremulous clouds
and continuing seemingly forever)
and up and over the mountain

Anyway the hangover
that comes from bourbon
in the hot tub and saunic discussions
about the nature of marriage
and justice and Tennessee
Williams strolls through sun
-banked curves snow-dusted
lodge pole and rim rock
and Sunday traffic lands me
at long last on my couch
with a needy cat who’s been
cooped up in the house
and this poem unspooling
toward a self-imposed deadline
of another day

But even if I pluck all the right words
out of the ether about my wife
sleeping against me in the too-big bed
or the snap of a frozen sage bush
or St. Vincent waxing eloquent
on Weekend Edition—freshly
erudite, languidly tart—or the dark
chasm the Columbia River
opens in my chest, it does nothing
to draw you closer to the truth
I’m immersed in but can’t touch

The gap between what I want
and what I achieve eternally
decreases. So I’ll finish the bourbon
and sink into the couch content
with my cat who demands nothing
of me or the world but a warm lap
and the slow steady motion
of my hand on her back

item.title: 53 – Taylorism
item.dc:creator: Graham
item.description: Taylorism I have broken this poem free of any meaning simplified into each distinct word a task you can replicate over and over & ovr
item.content:encoded:
Taylorism

I have broken this poem

free of any meaning

simplified into each

distinct word

a task

you

can

replicate

over

and

over

&

ovr

item.title: 52 – without a word
item.dc:creator: Graham
item.description: without a word we dig all day just the two of us without a word one shovel and its dull blade we cut the grass in a long row lay it out gently as he was foot by slow foot … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
without a word

we dig all day
just the two of us
without a word
one shovel
and its dull blade

we cut the grass
in a long row
lay it out
gently
as he was

foot by slow foot
we disappear
below ground
making the path
straight and narrow

robin’s egg sky
infinite blue rectangle
you stand at the edge
backlit head back
drinking from an old canteen

I think for sure
you mean to leave
the shovel buried
step down to me

catch the apple blossoms
the trees toss
down in mourning
without a word

item.title: 51 – A long night
item.dc:creator: Graham
item.description: A long night I long to crawl into her leopard hat inside a long-stem martini glass inside a bell a bell a bell hide between the notes slip beneath vermouth’s clean sheet sleep inside the black velvet lining bound up … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
A long night

I long to crawl into her leopard hat
inside a long-stem martini glass
inside a bell a bell a bell

hide between the notes
slip beneath vermouth’s clean sheet
sleep inside the black velvet lining

bound up in her golden tresses

item.title: 50 – Bitter Fruit
item.dc:creator: Graham
item.description: Bitter Fruit Dozens of mismatched sneakers or so it seems dangle from a pipe ell above the tarp tents under the bridge. I’m sorry I don’t have any change to spare; it’s busy being clutched by the hand in my … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Bitter Fruit

Dozens of mismatched sneakers
or so it seems
dangle from a pipe ell
above the tarp tents
under the bridge.

I’m sorry I don’t
have any change
to spare; it’s busy being
clutched by the hand
in my pocket.

On my way home
the homeless camp
is gone. The sneakers
still hang, twisting
in the wind.

I reach for strange fruit
and find the taste
bitter. My face goes
blurry like
in the picture.

Like the picture
I am always pointing;
I am always
walking quickly
away.

item.title: 49 – Big River
item.dc:creator: Graham
item.description: Big River (after reading Huck Finn) We say it (nudge-nudge) so often James sets down his dog-eared spine-broken book climbs up on the block his desk makes in protest. His dangling dreadlocks sound manacles. It suddenly smells of piss and … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Big River

(after reading Huck Finn)

We say it (nudge-nudge)
so often James
sets down his dog-eared
spine-broken book

climbs up on the block
his desk makes
in protest.

His dangling dreadlocks
sound manacles.

It suddenly smells of piss
and chattel-mud, though
outside this classroom
the night is fine.

Stomachs turn bile and vinegar.
Taste of shame.

White knuckles kiss
sweaty palms.

Don’t we float the Big River together?
Big wheel keep on turning.

That truck is trash.

That truck
is a sow’s ear. The truth?

Each wooden desk holds
only one. This raft weren’t lashed
to keep us all.

No matter.

Running aground,
busting up
each of us

water-logged cottonwoods
pulled by a muddy current
we can’t none of us stop as

mighty Mississippi rolls on

to the Gulf, open mouth
of salt and sorrow

sea’s freedom
seems preferable
someway
to swallowing truth.

item.title: 48 – Artifact
item.dc:creator: Graham
item.description: Artifact Fucking centrifugal force. Who ever threw a ceramic mug with a handle right the first time? Or fly fished. Or founded a state, say Florida or North Dakota, out there alone where the buffalo roam(ed). Or take federal holidays: … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Artifact

Fucking centrifugal force.
Who ever threw a ceramic mug
with a handle right the first time?
Or fly fished. Or founded a state,
say Florida or North Dakota, out there alone
where the buffalo roam(ed). Or take
federal holidays: let’s agree today
is the day we do nothing for no reason!
We’ll leave the legislation. Later gator.
It used to be pantaloons on the line
and dog fights in top-hatted circles
and delightfully even rows of corn
or amber waves of mono-culture grain,
a quick dip in the pond with the missus
on a summer night, fireflies that might bight,
aye, that’s the life for me! Now: nano-bots
surfing your blood and the NSA retweeting
your OK Cupid profile (pwned!). Next: future
of cars that don’t need no stinking roads
where we’re going, Marty. Oval eyes
and silver-mesh unitards, giant brains
hooked into gianter mainframes.
Tall, tall arboreal cities anchored in nothing
but dust and trash and a magmatic core.
Time capsule. Their scientists (ours?)
root with bionic arms through our plasticity
for endless crap and radioactive everything.
Someday they’ll turn up an ugly no-handle mug
with a lazy glaze job and chicken-scratch
etched in the bottom. Attempted perpetuity.
I wonder, they’ll say, what it is? What it means?
Some things never change.

item.title: 47 – Altiplano
item.dc:creator: Graham
item.description: Altiplano Ugly truth arrives half-empty Bohemia bottle whistles disbelief rage shatters glass brown-blown imploding binary star carved on the wall of a nowhere altiplano cantina. Field horses raise naggled heads in the sour  wind. Apologies are anguished litter; semantic glass … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Altiplano

Ugly truth arrives
half-empty Bohemia bottle
whistles disbelief

rage shatters glass
brown-blown
imploding binary star

carved on the wall
of a nowhere
altiplano cantina.

Field horses
raise naggled heads
in the sour  wind.

Apologies are anguished
litter; semantic glass
only nuzzles deeper.

World of men abandoned
for the emptiness
of dirt and grass

and the animal
instinct of herd
and scent.

Her hands mark
tattered manes,
bloodied muzzles

close, bulk warm
against her own
stretched neck.

She knows of hobble.
Half a world away
plans fold all wrong:

a useless map
of a city she’s never seen
buried in a lost pocket.

The shared key
broken off
in the lock;

the common address
on a street with a name
she can’t recall

and would not
return to tonight
if she could.

She curls
in the far corner
of the pasture.

The herd gathers.
Long bodies
and all seeing eyes

make vigil;
she sleeps
as they sleep

under sky,
a standing circle
ringed around her.

item.title: 46 – Solitaire
item.dc:creator: Graham
item.description: Solitaire I was up at the cemetery when the bridge closed. It was a dry run. The rain ruined my tux. It was a rental. I hid in the mouth of a mausoleum and played solitaire with dead leaves. A … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Solitaire

I was up at the cemetery
when the bridge closed.
It was a dry run.
The rain ruined my tux.
It was a rental.
I hid in the mouth
of a mausoleum
and played solitaire
with dead leaves.
A pair of headless angels
offered alternative routes:
the freeway was too risky;
my shoes and cufflinks
would drown me.
The ace of spades
kept on not rolling.
A boy practiced wide turns
in his parents minivan
for an hour. I waved once.
No fresh flowers. No tiny flags.
Just tall trees hovering over
a claw-armed backhoe.
I used my rented cummerbund
to clean the pioneer markers,
propped up their rotten crosses.
Sounds of grinding life
on the dead bridge drifted up
the hill. I asked the angels
how long. They couldn’t say.
I shuffled and shuffled
again. The dead leaves fed
into one another. The game
went on.
